title: Will Nancy Pelosi be re-elected as Speaker of the House of Representatives in the 117th Congress?
preds: breaking: "House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), the only woman to serve as speaker, was reelected by a narrow margin in a closely divided House." https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/01/02/new-congress-live-updates/

Update to previous forecasts. Increase to 99% for elapsed time and the impending vote anticipated for later today, 3 JAN 21, or soon thereafter. There is no new evidence supporting claims of additional breaks within the House that would preclude Pelosi from retaining her speakership. COVID exposure limiting democratic House members from voting remains marginal.  https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/03/politics/nancy-pelosi-speaker-vote/index.html

While many democrats voted for someone else in 2019, House Democrats are holding leadership elections as they grapple with unexpected losses and the prospects for a Congress that remains divided. The GOP appears likely to maintain control of the Senate. Plus House Republicans picked up at least eight seats, and several races are too close to call. It is likely that democrats will rally together to protect the influence of the party in the legislative branch.
https://www.npr.org/2020/11/18/935718252/pelosi-set-to-be-reelected-speaker-despite-house-losses
Seems exceptionally likely but not certain.
Democrats still have a slight majority, and she is entrenched.

AOC and others have questioned supporting Pelosi but then they are also wary of someone more conservative taking her place. 50/50 -  for: status quo and experience  - against:  desire for a new guard. Will undoubtedly be tight.
Back to 100.  No dems are reporting too sick to fly next week to DC. No major storms in the 8 day forecast.
If she cheats as usual/secures CCP confidence... perhaps. Otherwise no. Her own party recognizes they can't stay afloat forever on a sinking ship.

Inching back up to 99%. Great overview of the situation as of today by the AP: "There’s little doubt that Nancy Pelosi will be reelected House speaker when the new Congress convenes Sunday. It could take a high-wire act for her to get there, largely thanks to the pandemic ... Democrats will have a 222-211 edge, with one race still undecided and one vacancy after Rep.-elect Luke Letlow, R-La., died Tuesday after battling COVID-19 ... The raging coronavirus pandemic, combined with routine illnesses and the usual risks of wintertime travel, could make attendance unpredictable for the first House roll call in months that lawmakers will have to attend in person ... No Democratic rival to Pelosi has emerged, greatly diminishing the odds she’ll be toppled ... Even so, Pelosi must minimize the number of Democrats opposing her ... Some suggest the tight numbers might encourage Pelosi’s Democratic critics to force the balloting into a rare second round, when she could eventually win but perhaps be forced into promises about bills the House would consider or other concessions." [1] Note that to be elected speaker, Pelosi only has to obtain an absolute majority of votes — not an absolute majority of the full membership of the House [2]. [1] https://apnews.com/article/mariannette-miller-meeks-nancy-pelosi-coronavirus-pandemic-house-elections-a464d77ee21dcfbe1002afe7a317b48d
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives

This intersting scenario I never considered. Basically, members MUST attend  Jan 3 session to vote for speaker and then to approve rules allowing remote proxy voting. No rempte voting allowed.  So if a democrat congressperson is sick they can not attend and vote, and some members may choose not to risk illness and travel.  So have Dems have a 10 seat majority(222 to 212?). If 11 do not show up and all Republkcans show then  guess who wins? Also if Pelosi supporters stay away then a Democrat may be speaker but it won't be Pelosi.  Pelosi always has opposition from within her party, would the opposition seize the moment to unseat her eve  if means pjnishing party members who were sick or afraid to attend in person.  https://thehill.com/homenews/house/530945-covid-19-could-complicate-pelosis-path-to-speaker-next-year
How does this impact my 100% pelosi forecast? I am reducing by 10%. It is arbitrary, but i can't believe the Dem would be so dysfunctional as to allow a Republican speaker.  Pelosi is intelligent and has demonstrated an abilith to keep the causus in line, but IF the opportjnity presented itself wouldn't progressives seize it?

She will survive, if only to outlast President Trump and make sure the Electoral College vote is done decently and in order when it comes to House participation. She may be working to outlast Mitch McConnell.
She will endure, but there will be heartburn about it.

"Speaker Nancy Pelosi had a blunt message for her junior members: I need your vote on Jan. 3 ... No one on Capitol Hill believes Pelosi is really at risk of losing the gavel. But the vote has become much more complicated with a shrunken Democratic majority and the coronavirus pandemic shadowing the proceedings ... According to House rules, Pelosi must win a majority of votes cast 'for a person by name' of the members who are in attendance and voting. So Pelosi can afford to allow a handful of her members to vote 'present,' but a vote for anyone else is more problematic ... At least two Democrats plan to vote against Pelosi on the floor: Reps. Conor Lamb of Pennsylvania and Jared Golden of Maine, according to several sources. A third, Rep. Abigail Spanberger of Virginia, could also vote 'no,' though she declined to comment in a recent interview ... A single Democrat forced to stay home because of an infection or quarantine period — not to mention other health issues — could upset Pelosi’s careful balancing act." https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/11/nancy-pelosi-speaker-vote-444409 Revising downward to 96%, as this might be closer than I previously thought it would be.

Pelosi has suggested that she will serve this term, and is unlikely to meet meaningful opposition from her own party.

To be elected speaker a candidate needs a majority of the votes cast, which currently is 218 votes in the 435 representatives of the House. There have only been a few instances where a person did not receive the majority of the full membership (last Boehner in 2015 but he still was elected with 216). The democrats held a 232 to 197 majority in the 116th Congress and waiting or dust to settle for the 117th Congress will still hold the majority. Although Pelosi had 15 people vote against her last time, a strong democratic unity platform is being pushed.
Democrats voted to keep her as their nominee as she ran unopposed, and full house vote will have the same outcome with Democratic control.

"Democrats in the US House of Representatives voted on Wednesday to keep House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in her job for another two years, despite the party losing seats to Republicans in the Nov. 3 election. The full House still must vote for speaker in early January, when Republicans will put up their own candidate for the job but are likely to lose since they will be in the minority in the 435-seat chamber."
https://www.cnbctv18.com/politics/house-democrats-back-pelosi-for-another-term-as-speaker-7518241.htm

Today, House democrats re-affirmed Nancy Pelosi as their leader via virtual election. She ran unopposed within the party. She will now need to secure a majority vote when the 117th session of Congress convenes come January.  As of today, democrats hold a 13 seat advantage over republicans in the House, with 10 seats still unconfirmed. Even if all 10 go to republican candidates (unlikely), democrats still hold majority power. While far left house members and some democratic centrists may oppose Pelosi's speakership, it remains incredibly unlikely they would collectively muster enough dissention, as it could unintendedly provoke a Republican ascension given the narrow margins at play.  https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/18/us/politics/democrats-nominate-nancy-pelosi-for-another-term-as-speaker-as-she-suggests-it-could-be-her-last.html

Nancy Pelosi has been reelected speaker of the House by her caucus for the next session of Congress, marking what will be her fourth term with the gavel. The caucus vote was conducted virtually, but Pelosi was approved with a voice vote. Currently, the democrats have the majority of seats in the house.

My understanding of the current state of the House is that the Democrats have secured a small majority (currently just one seat). Of the 12 seats that have not yet been decided the Republican Party leads in 10. Accordingly, the Democrats are likely to only have a very small majority in the House.  My guess is that the Democratic party (in the House) do not want to re-elect Nancy Pelosi as Speaker, and given the (expected) net loss of seats in the election, it may provide an opportunity for change. Furthermore, Joe Biden ran on a ticket of cohesion and his ability to 'work across the aisle', I don't feel as though Nancy Pelosi is the best embodiment of that philosophy.
Pelosi has survived and exceeded expectations many times before ...

There will be too much fragmentation among those who oppose her.  Further, the 'heat' Progressives are taking over Democratic losses and near-losses in the recent election has taken some of their power away.

Currently the Speaker of the House is not being challenged openly by any party competitors. That being said, the margin of majority has shrunk for the Democrats in the House, therefore it would only take a handful of contradictory or abstained votes to challenge this re-election. However, given that small window and the fact that Speaker Pelosi was challenged in 2016 and won by a large amount, provides a clearer path to re-election.

People tend to continue what they have already done in the past.  The potential change would be because there are less moderate democrats in the House.  It appears the the house has more republicans and more progressive democrats than the last session.

Nancy Pelosi has survived serious challenges from the left and minor challenges from the right side of the democratic party. Her strongest challenges have come from the left, the side of the party that suffered major setbacks this election cycle. Therefore, I think it is highly likely that she is re-elected Speaker of the House
No likely opposition among democrats has emerged. If anything, the results of the election solidified moderate democrat views over progressives such as AOC.

With Pelosi's promise to step down in the '22 elections, a growing distaste for the more vocal, progressive left among centrist democrats and republicans and ongoing plans to support Biden's Presidency, there is a very high probability of continued Pelosi leadership in the House.

I haven't seen an indication of challenger. She agreed to a 2-term limit in 2018 when she fought to regain the speakership.
https://www.rollcall.com/2018/12/12/pelosi-agrees-to-deal-limiting-her-speakership-to-4-years/
This 2021-2023 term would be her second and last, per her agreement with the caucus. Perspiration, not inspiration, is called for in this term's speakership. This Speaker is no stranger to hard work, nor to pressure points, nor to triangulation. The 117th can be expected to be contentious. A stimulus package is important for the new President to get his administration off on the right foot. Any package will require the  the pre-buy-in of enough in the Senate first, and then the agility to twist arms in the House, to get it to the finish line. She will have a friendly White House, and so will have some help in jawboning. But it still requires legislative savvy, something both Biden and Pelosi have in their respective chambers.  I see nothing that indicates a desire or need to change that equation.

For the last decade, Pelosi has had the same post-election routine: swiftly quashing whispers of an insurrection as a handful of members look to end her long tenure as leader. But this year, Pelosi is poised to enter another — and possibly final term — as speaker, with her position as safe as ever despite losing at least six net seats after predicting they’d expand their majority.
(no change) Until the US Prez election is "sorted out" I doubt if there will be any discussion related to the new House Speaker.

At the moment, no other house democrats are challenging Nancy Pelosi for the position of speaker of the house. The opposition to her candidacy seems to be venting of progressive grievances and members bargaining for policies.

A truly terrible idea for the Ds, but she's probably a shoo-in.   It hasn't been good for their numbers that their Senate and their House leader are both Coastal Crazies.

Initial forecast. Below the consensus. NP has had a very credible career, but is also a bit of a lightning rod for red and purple states. While facing DT it might have been "necessary" to keep the post, but now with JB president elect and a close Senate (and more importantly a chance that the crazy rhetoric may be "old school") a change may make sense. I think NP will do the right thing. Although sometimes when Speakers go to pasture they resign, I don't believe that is required. Just being in the Congress and perhaps offering insight would still be a pretty good gig. Likely to lose (gain) Brier points on this.

Base Rate: Over the past 120 years (60 congresses), there have been 25 changes in speakers. Of those, 11 have been because the  party in power changed. The other 14 were within party changes.  They are:  Ryan replacing Boehner (2015) - Boehner didn't run for office
Haster replacing Gingrich (1999) - Gingrich had many scandals and Rs underperformed. 
Foley replacing Wright (1989) - Wright was subjected to an ethics inquiry and he resigned. 
Wright replacing O'Neill (1987) - O'Neill retired from congress
O'Neill replacing Albert (1977) - Albert retired amidst a scandal
Albert replacing McCormack (1971) - Discord within the House cased McCormack to not run for reelection
McCormack replacing Rayburn (1961) - Rayburn died 
Rayburn replaces Bankhead (1940) - Bankhead died
Bankhead replaces Byrns (1936) - Byrns died
Byrns replaces Rainey (1934) - Rainey died
Rainey replaces Garner (1933) - Garner became VP
Longworth replaces Gillet (1925) - Gillet became a senator
Cannon replaces Henderson (1903) - Henderson did not run for office
Henderson replaces Reed (1899) - Reed did not run for office Long story short, the HOR speaker has resigned on a few occasions, but always before seeking reelection, not after achieving reelection to their House of Representatives position. Thus, I would conclude the base-rate is about 100%. Inside take: This election didn't go poorly enough for Pelosi to suggest she should resign. They won the White House, are still competitive for the senate, and lost only a few seats in the house. All in all, a good outcome for Ds. Though some are suggesting she should resign, I think that broadly she has a lot of support.  [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Speakers_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives
There does not seem to be a viable contender at this point, and she has support from the progressives in the party.  However, some are disappointed in the outcome of the elections to the house.
